questions.text: All of the following are examples of Dermal melanocytosis Ceruloderma except?

A 43-year-old man reports persistent facial redness around his nose and cheeks for several months. The flushing worsens after alcohol intake, though he drinks only about 14 units per week. On examination, there is erythema over the central face with telangiectasia on the cheeks and pustules over the nose. There is no scaling on the scalp or eyebrows. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Linear IgA deposits at the dermoepidermal junction
Loss of fibrinogen at the basement membrane
Granular IgG along the basement membrane
IgG and C3 at the dermoepidermal junction

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman presents with several days of intense pruritus followed by the development of tense bullae on the inner thighs and upper arms. The blisters are filled with clear fluid and are not easily ruptured. A skin biopsy is performed, and direct immunofluorescence is ordered. Which of the following findings is most likely?
questions.solution: Ans. D) IgG and C3 at the dermoepidermal junction

questions.text: Hemidesmosomes are specialized adhesion structures found in the skin. They are essential for anchoring which of the following structures together?

A 23-year-old woman presents with erythematous patches over both cheeks. The redness is sharply demarcated and characteristically spares the nasolabial folds. She reports increased rash intensity after sun exposure. There are no pustules or comedones. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 43-year-old patient presents with a 2-month history of itchy lesions on the soles of the feet. Examination shows small, deep-seated blisters along with surrounding dry, cracked skin. No mucosal lesions are present. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old man presents with acute onset of painful, grouped vesicles on an erythematous base distributed along the right T3 dermatome. The lesions do not cross the midline. He also reports burning pain and tingling in the area for the past 2 days before the rash appeared. Which virus is most likely responsible for this presentation?

A 23-year-old man presents with a sudden onset patch of hair loss on the left temporal scalp. The skin in the area appears normal, without scaling, erythema, or scarring. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 29-year-old man presents with a complaint of "hard skin" on his scalp. Examination reveals a 9 cm circular, white, hyperkeratotic plaque on the crown of his head. He has no history of previous scalp or skin disease. Skin scrapings for fungal elements are negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old man presents with an extensive, malodorous ulcer on the glans penis. The ulcer has exuberant, beefy-red granulation tissue and bleeds easily on touch. There is no associated inguinal lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely causative organism?
A patient infected with an RNA virus activates Toll-like receptors (TLRs) that recognize single-stranded viral RNA inside endosomes. Which of the following TLRs is responsible for this recognition?

choices.text: Both A and R are true and R explains A
Both A and R are true but R does not explain A
A is true but R is false
Both A and R are false

questions.text:
Assertion (A): A deficiency of C5–C9 complement components predisposes to recurrent Neisseria infections.
Reason (R): The membrane attack complex is required for opsonization and phagocytosis of Gram-negative bacteria.
questions.solution: Ans. C) A is true but R is false

questions.text: A blood culture from a febrile patient grows Gram-negative rods, resistant to carbapenems but sensitive to aztreonam. Which enzyme is responsible?
Phage typing of Staphylococcus aureus helps in identifying different strains based on:

A 45-year-old HIV-positive man presents with headache, fever, and neck stiffness. CSF analysis shows lymphocytic pleocytosis with mildly elevated protein. Culture on Sabouraud’s agar grows creamy, mucoid colonies. India ink preparation of the CSF is given. What is the major virulence factor responsible for this organism’s pathogenicity?

A 45-year-old farmer presents with a rapidly spreading, foul-smelling, necrotic wound on his leg after sustaining a deep laceration while working in the fields. Examination reveals crepitus and extensive tissue necrosis. Gram stain of the wound shows Gram-positive rods. Culture grows Clostridium perfringens. Which toxin is a Lecithinase responsible for the tissue necrosis seen in this patient?

A 3-year-old boy presents with severe, recurrent bacterial infections, including pneumonia and otitis media. He has very low levels of all immunoglobulins but normal T-cell counts. Which condition is most likely?
A Segmented, negative-sense RNA virus that undergoes reassortment causing pandemics. Which virus is most likely responsible?

A microbiologist is testing two antibiotics together against a bacterial strain to see if they work better combined than alone. She plots bacterial counts over time while exposing the bacteria to the drug combination. What is this test primarily used to assess?
A 28-year-old man presents with intermittent fever and swelling of his lower limbs. A peripheral blood smear taken at night is given below. Which stage of the parasite is infective for humans?

A 55-year-old immunocompromised patient presents with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. A bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) culture shows septate hyphae branching at acute angles. Which virulence factor of this organism primarily helps it invade tissue?

A 25-year-old contact lens wearer presents with pain, redness, and decreased vision in one eye for the past week. A corneal scraping is sent for fungal culture. Lactophenol cotton blue (LPCB) mount given below. What is the most likely organism?

Which of the following statements about the causative organism, Legionella pneumophila, are true?

  1. Requires cysteine and iron for growth
  2. Easily grows on standard blood agar
  3. Can be detected by urine antigen test
  4. Grows on BCYE agar
A traveler receives the oral live-attenuated typhoid vaccine before visiting an endemic area. Which type of immunity is primarily induced by this vaccine?

A 35-year-old HIV-positive patient presents with multiple molluscum-like papules over the face and trunk, along with fever and weight loss. Skin biopsy shows yeast cells with transverse septa. Which of the following best describes the organism’s appearance at 25°C?

A 7-year-old child develops bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps 2 days after eating undercooked beef. Stool culture shows non-sorbitol fermenting Escherichia coli. The toxin produced by this organism is most similar to which of the following?

A 22-year-old patient with cystic fibrosis presents with fever, increasing cough, and greenish sputum. Sputum culture grows Gram-negative rods with blue-green pigment and fruity odor. What is the name of the blue-green pigment produced by this organism?

A 50-year-old patient presents with urinary tract infection. Urine culture grows Escherichia coli. The lab performs antimicrobial susceptibility testing (AST). On the culture plate, antibiotic discs are placed on a bacterial lawn, and clear areas appear around some discs. Which AST method shows zones of inhibition around antibiotic discs?

A 12-year-old child presents with persistent perianal itching, occasional abdominal discomfort, and intermittent diarrhea. Stool examination and history raise suspicion for parasites capable of autoinfection, allowing them to complete their life cycle within the host. Which of the following parasites are known for autoinfection?

  1. Strongyloides stercoralis
  2. Enterobius vermicularis
  3. Taenia solium
  4. Ascaris lumbricoides
A 35-year-old farmer presents with high-grade fever, malaise, and mild hepatitis. Liver biopsy shows image below. Which pathogen is most likely responsible for this infection?

choices.text: Expert witnesses can testify about something even if they did not personally observe it, as long as it is accepted in their field of expertise.
Expert witnesses must never testify about anything they did not personally witness or participate in.
Expert witness cannot be considered hostile witness.
Expert witnesses are required to have prior experience testifying in court to be considered qualified.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the witness in the court?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Expert witnesses can testify about something even if they did not personally observe, as long as it is accepted in their field of expertise.

questions.text: In a trial, the defence lawyer is questioning a forensic expert summoned by him to challenge the prosecution’s evidence. What is this called?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Direct examination by the defence

choices.text: The patient's family (plaintiffs), because they are accusing the doctor of negligence.
Dr. Singh, because he must prove that his clinical decision was based on standard medical practice.
The hospital, because it is the employer and responsible for the actions of its staff under vicarious liability.
Shared between the patient's family and the hospital, as both need to provide evidence to support or refute the claim.

questions.text: A 45-year male, Mr. Sharma without any relevant past medical history, visits Dr. Singh in a hospital with abdominal discomfort. Dr. Singh makes a diagnosis of gastritis and prescribes antacids. Hours later, he suffers a heart attack. His family sues Dr. Singh and the hospital for medical negligence, alleging failure to order cardiac tests. Who bears the onus of proof in this civil negligence case?
questions.solution: Ans. A) The patient's family (plaintiffs), because they are accusing the doctor of negligence.

choices.text: Left and right hand prints of an individual are identical; only the orientation of the hand changes.
Fingerprints are not much useful helpful in childhood for identification.
The probability of two individuals having identical fingerprints is practically zero, even for identical twins.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the fingerprints is most accurate?
questions.solution: Ans. C) The probability of two individuals having identical fingerprints is practically zero, even for identical twins.

choices.text: Rapid dehydration due to high temperature and low humidity, preventing bacterial decomposition
Low temperature and low humidity, reducing the rate of enzymatic breakdown and slowing decomposition

questions.text: A body is discovered in an isolated cave with signs of mummification, with the skin and organs becoming dry and leathery. What is the primary cause of this preservation process?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Rapid dehydration due to high temperature and low humidity, preventing bacterial decomposition

questions.text: The image below is seen in?
Which method of asphyxiation listed below is almost always considered to be homicidal in nature?
Which of the following supports malingering (feigned insanity)?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Vague and dramatic symptoms

questions.text: A 40-year man presents with mild confusion, dizziness, and slight unsteadiness while walking. He consumed a large amount of alcohol 6 hours back. His anion gap, blood pH, calcium and serum bicarbonate are all normal. Which is the likely cause of his symptoms?

A 25-year male presents after ingesting oxalic acid. He has severe burning pain in throat and difficulty in breathing due to laryngeal edema. His BP is normal but appears restless. Lab tests reveal metabolic acidosis. Most appropriate immediate intervention?

A 26-year-old female patient was diagnosed with a moderate depressive episode. She was initiated on pharmacotherapy and achieved a satisfactory remission of depressive symptoms. However, she now complains of distressing sexual dysfunction in the form of diminished libido and anorgasmia. She requests an alternative antidepressant that is not commonly associated with sexual side effects. Which of the following is the most appropriate choice?

A 48-year-old man with a 20-year history of heavy alcohol use is admitted for planned detoxification. He reports previous withdrawal symptoms including tremors and sweating. On Day 2 of admission, he becomes disoriented and agitated. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for developing alcohol withdrawal delirium in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Prior history of delirium tremens

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman survives a road traffic accident in which her friend died. Within 3 days, she develops intrusive memories, nightmares, dissociation, and hypervigilance. She is unable to sleep and avoids reminders of the accident. These symptoms have persisted for 4 days. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old woman with severe depression is scheduled for electroconvulsive therapy (ECT). The anesthesiologist is asked to choose an induction agent and a muscle relaxant that will ensure rapid recovery and minimal interference with seizure duration. Which combination is most appropriate?

choices.text: They are as clear as a real perception
Patient does not have any control over the perception
They occur without any external stimulus
They are experienced in the objective space

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not correct for pseudo-hallucinations?
questions.solution: Ans. D) They are experienced in the objective space

questions.text: A 22-year-old college student is brought to the emergency department by his friends after he reports having “weird experiences” following consumption of a substance at a party. He says, “Whenever I listen to music, I start seeing colorful geometric figures like triangles and circles floating in the air.” He appears calm and oriented, and his vitals are stable. There is no history of loss of consciousness, seizures, or any psychiatric illness. Which of the following terms best describes this phenomenon?

A 28-year-old man presents to the psychiatrist with repetitive distressing thoughts that his wife is cheating on him. He reports that he knows these thoughts are not true but cannot stop them despite trying hard. He repeatedly asks his wife for reassurance, feels guilty afterward, and says the thoughts keep coming back against his will. What is the underlying psychopathology?

A medical student was asked, “From which institute do you want to pursue your post-graduation?” He replied, “Post-graduation has become a necessity nowadays and because of the increasing number of doctors, I feel the opportunities for successful practice are decreasing. I think doctors should consider going into related branches like the pharma industry, and my uncle owns a small pharma company and he wants me to join it.” What is the thought abnormality demonstrated in this response?

A 46-year-old man presents to the psychiatric clinic accompanied by his worried wife. He has a 6-month history of severe depression and recently started making alarming statements about his physical health. He repeatedly says that he can “feel his intestines rotting inside him” and believes he is decaying from within. He has visited several gastroenterologists, all of whom have found no abnormalities. Despite repeated medical reassurances, he remains firmly convinced of his belief. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
A patient with schizophrenia says, “Yes, I hear some voices, but no, I don’t have any illness.” What is the grade of insight in this patient?
